articles.headline: New Orleans Police, Mired in Scandal, Accept Plan for Overhaul
articles.snippet: The far-reaching agreement with the Justice Department is also intended to improve safety in a city that has had little of it.
articles.abstract: The far-reaching agreement with the Justice Department is also intended to improve safety in a city that has had little of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The New Orleans Police Department and the United States Department of Justice announced a far-reaching agreement on Tuesday to overhaul the city’s scandal-ridden police force and improve safety in a city that has had little of it.

articles.headline: Bond Trading Loses Some Swagger Amid Upheaval
articles.snippet: Tighter regulations and new technology are threatening to constrain a bastion of bonuses and risk-taking.
articles.abstract: Tighter regulations and new technology are threatening to constrain a bastion of bonuses and risk-taking.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bond traders have long defined Wall Street’s swagger and, in good years, generated a large share of its profits. Now, though, an upheaval is taking place in the bond business that is wiping out billions in profits and thousands of jobs.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Softer Sales of iPhones Hurt Apple
articles.snippet: Apple sold 28 percent more iPhones last quarter than it did a year earlier, but the growth failed to meet the lofty expectations of analysts.
articles.abstract: Apple sold 28 percent more iPhones last quarter than it did a year earlier, but the growth failed to meet the lofty expectations of analysts.
articles.lead_paragraph: It looks as if many people are so sure the next iPhone is going to be good that they are not buying the ones Apple is selling now.

articles.headline: Fed Leaning Closer to New Stimulus if No Growth Is Seen
articles.snippet: A growing number of officials have concluded that the Federal Reserve needs to expand its stimulus campaign unless the economy soon shows signs of improvement.
articles.abstract: A growing number of officials have concluded that the Federal Reserve needs to expand its stimulus campaign unless the economy soon shows signs of improvement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A growing number of Federal Reserve officials have concluded that the central bank needs to expand its stimulus campaign unless the nation’s economy soon shows signs of improvement, including job growth.

articles.headline: Congress to Examine Data Sellers
articles.snippet: Data brokers, companies that collect consumer information and sell it, are being asked to give details about how they work, and that could lead to more regulation.
articles.abstract: Data brokers, companies that collect consumer information and sell it, are being asked to give details about how they work, and that could lead to more regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a move that could lay bare the inner workings of the consumer data industry, eight members of Congress have opened a sweeping investigation into data brokers — companies that collect, collate, analyze and sell billions of details annually about consumers’ offline, online and mobile activities for marketing and other purposes.

articles.headline: Romney Blasts Security Leaks as a Betrayal
articles.snippet: On the eve of a trip abroad intended to burnish his presidential qualifications, Mitt Romney opened a new and aggressive attack against President Obama on national security.
articles.abstract: On the eve of a trip abroad intended to burnish his presidential qualifications, Mitt Romney opened a new and aggressive attack against President Obama on national security.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — On the eve of a trip abroad intended to burnish his qualifications to be commander in chief, Mitt Romney accused Obama administration officials on Tuesday of betraying the country by leaking national security secrets for their own political gain and failing to stand up to adversaries like China, Russia and Iran.

articles.headline: Al Qaeda Taking Deadly New Role in Syria’s Conflict
articles.snippet: The terrorist network has helped to alter the Syrian revolution, injecting the weapon it perfected in Iraq — suicide bombings — into the battle against President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.abstract: The terrorist network has helped to alter the Syrian revolution, injecting the weapon it perfected in Iraq — suicide bombings — into the battle against President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — It is the sort of image that has become a staple of the Syrian revolution, a video of masked men calling themselves the Free Syrian Army and brandishing AK-47s — with one unsettling difference. In the background hang two flags of Al Qaeda, white Arabic writing on a black field.

articles.headline: Bank Analyst Sees No Payoff in a Customer-Friendly Focus
articles.snippet: Annoyed by poor customer service, an analyst took his money out of Wells Fargo but didn’t change his rosy assessment of the bank’s strength.
articles.abstract: Annoyed by poor customer service, an analyst took his money out of Wells Fargo but didn’t change his rosy assessment of the bank’s strength.
articles.lead_paragraph: First came the unhelpful bank tellers. Then the unexplained monthly fees. Then the fumbled mortgage application.

articles.headline: Mogul’s Latest Foray Courts Jews for the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The Republican Jewish Coalition, backed by the casino magnate Sheldon Adelson, is starting a new effort in battleground states to win over Jewish voters.
articles.abstract: The Republican Jewish Coalition, backed by the casino magnate Sheldon Adelson, is starting a new effort in battleground states to win over Jewish voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Republican group backed by the casino magnate Sheldon Adelson is starting a new effort in battleground states to win over Jewish voters who could be persuaded to turn away from President Obama and support Mitt Romney.

articles.headline: That Mystery Woman in North Korea? Turns Out She’s the First Lady
articles.snippet: The appearance of Kim Jong-un’s wife is a sign that he is breaking from the style of his father, who was known for marrying beautiful performers but never introduced them to his people.
articles.abstract: The appearance of Kim Jong-un’s wife is a sign that he is breaking from the style of his father, who was known for marrying beautiful performers but never introduced them to his people.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — She was first spotted at a gala concert for the country’s who’s who, dressed in a trim black suit in the Chanel tradition. Then she popped up at a kindergarten, trailing photographers who caught images of her smiling gently at children playing on a slide. Her latest appearance, at the inauguration of an amusement park, was yet another star turn: the cameras zooming in on the slim woman with the easy smile and fashionable polka-dot jacket.

articles.headline: The Payout in an Apple Upgrade
articles.snippet: Apple offers Mountain Lion, a new version of its OS X software for the Mac. With “over 200 new features,” it costs $20, but is it worth it?
articles.abstract: Apple offers Mountain Lion, a new version of its OS X software for the Mac. With “over 200 new features,” it costs $20, but is it worth it?
articles.lead_paragraph: A new version of Windows is a big, big deal. Big changes, big price, big installation.

articles.headline: Weill Calls for Splitting Up Big Banks
articles.snippet: They were words no one ever expected Sanford I. Weill to utter. “What we should probably do,” said the man who helped usher in the age of the financial supermarket, “is go and split up investment banking from banking.”
articles.abstract: They were words no one ever expected Sanford I. Weill to utter. “What we should probably do,” said the man who helped usher in the age of the financial supermarket, “is go and split up investment banking from banking.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In politics, it is called flip-flopping. In banking, it is called postcrisis regrets.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Severe Drought Seen as Driving Cost of Food Up
articles.snippet: The Agriculture Department said the cost of beef would increase the most, up to 5 percent, because of the weather and rising prices for animal feed.
articles.abstract: The Agriculture Department said the cost of beef would increase the most, up to 5 percent, because of the weather and rising prices for animal feed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Scorching heat and the worst drought in nearly a half-century are threatening to send food prices up, spooking consumers and leading to worries about global food costs.
articles.byline: By Annie Lowrey and Ron Nixon
